item.title: India’s Hindu Right Seems Unstoppable. This City Shows How.
item.description: Muslims make up a majority in Sambhal, but after deadly clashes over a mosque, they say they the arms of the state are now stifling them.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: The Shahi Jama Masjid mosque in Sambhal, India, was the site of violent clashes between Muslims and the police in November 2024.

item.title: Ukrainian Women Tell Their Stories of Sexual Violence by Russian Soldiers
item.description: Hundreds of Ukrainian women and girls have reported sexual violence by Russian troops during the four-year war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Sara Cincurova
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Darya with her mother near Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, in June. Darya said a drunken Russian soldier had forced his hands into her underwear and shouted “I want a young body!”

item.title: A New U.S. Blockade Is Strangling Cuba
item.description: An analysis of ship movements shows that the Trump administration is isolating the island at one of its most vulnerable moments.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: The oil tanker Ocean Mariner at the port of Havana last month. Cuba is facing the United States’ first effective blockade since the Cuban Missile Crisis.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Upends Royal Family’s Effort to Move Past His Scandal
item.description: King Charles III’s family, long rocked by infighting and grievous losses, is facing what could be the gravest threat to its moral authority in more than a generation.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, center, the brother of King Charles III, after leaving a police station on Thursday.

item.title: China’s ‘King of Banned Films’ Wants to Change the Subject
item.description: Acclaimed overseas for defying censors, Lou Ye is more interested in reaching Chinese audiences, as he holds up a cinematic mirror to their lives in modern China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chinese director Lou Ye, at his studio in Beijing in November.

item.title: U.K. Police Contacting Security Officers Who Once Protected Former Prince Andrew
item.description: The authorities also searched a mansion used by Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, who was arrested in connection with an investigation into suspicion of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor has shocked Britain and made headlines around the world.

item.title: Palestinian-American Teenager Killed in West Bank Is Laid to Rest
item.description: Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, was shot dead by an Israeli settler, according to a witness and Palestinian health officials, amid rising violent settler attacks in the Israeli-occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:description: The funeral of Nasrallah Abu Siyam, 19, in Mukhmas, a village in the West Bank, on Thursday, a day after he was killed.

item.title: An Enemy’s Fall Frees Up South Korea’s Leader. Now Comes the Tough Part.
item.description: President Lee Jae Myung gained legitimacy from his predecessor’s conviction​. But South Korea’s political polarization is caustic, and could get worse.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Jae Myung at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea in 2024.

item.title: A Makeup Ban in Syria for Women in Government and Public Sector Stirs Outrage
item.description: A provincial governor wants to prohibit women in government and public sector jobs from wearing makeup, stirring outrage and many, many memes.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women spending time at a cafe in Latakia, Syria, in May.

item.title: Iran Says U.S. Has Not Asked It to Stop Enriching Uranium
item.description: The comments by Iran’s foreign minister on Friday contradicted the Trump administration’s position.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Abbas Araghchi, the foreign minister of Iran, at the United Nations office in Geneva. The United States and Iran have been in Switzerland negotiating a nuclear deal this week.

item.title: How China Is Stoking Fear About Travel to Japan
item.description: From earthquake warnings to bear attack alerts, Beijing is deploying a campaign of exaggeration and disinformation to punish Tokyo’s support for Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Visitors on a street decorated for the Lunar New Year at China Town in Yokohama near Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: By Day, Cortina D’Ampezzo Is an Olympic Hub. By Night, It’s a Party.
item.description: Cortina d’Ampezzo, a small Alpine town in northern Italy, is hosting much of the Winter Games. It’s also a home away from home for rich partygoers.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Filippo Borghi mixing a cocktail at the Hôtel de la Poste, a famous nightspot in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: Olympics Gold Medalist Eclipsed By Her Toddler
item.description: A champion speedskater spoke to reporters with her toddler. The focus on her child was among several instances at the Olympics that highlighted the complexities working mothers face in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Italian speedskater Francesca Lollobrigida won two gold medals and set an Olympic record at the Games in Milan.

item.title: Venezuela Passes Amnesty Bill Denounced by Some as ‘Unjust’
item.description: The bill may bring the release of hundreds of political prisoners. But many critics say the legislation, passed after major pressure from the Trump administration, raises concerns.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Annie Correal, Patricia Sulbarán, Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Families gathered last month for a vigil outside El Rodeo I, a prison east of Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: How Olympic Experts Keep the Ice Intact
item.description: A team of skilled technicians and drivers keep the frozen surface at the right temperature and thickness. The challenge? Each event needs a different kind of ice.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère
item.media:description: Ice-resurfacing machines known as Zambonis restore the frozen surface of competition before, during and after Winter Olympics competitions.

item.title: Russia Takes the Gulag Out of the Gulag History Museum in Moscow
item.description: The museum had preserved the history of brutality inflicted by the Soviet Union on its people. It will now focus on Nazi war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition at the Gulag History Museum in Moscow in 2022. There are plans to turn the space into a Museum of Memory focused on Nazi war crimes.

item.title: Hungary Poses Unexpected Hurdle to Europe’s 90-Billion Euro Loan to Ukraine
item.description: While the delay may prove to be procedural, Hungary signaled that it could cause problems as the European Union works to send money to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The Hungarian foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, in Prague, Czech Republic, last month.

item.title: 3 People Are Killed in Series of Avalanches in Austrian Alps
item.description: The police said several other rescues took place. The avalanches happened amid severe weather warnings across the region.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Melina Delkic and Amy Graff

item.title: Ferreira completes his halfpipe set with gold.
item.description: The American Alex Ferreira nailed his final run to win gold in the ski halfpipe.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.description: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Mr. Wren in an undated photo. Explaining why he went into journalism, he said, “I wanted to find a job where I could go out and satisfy my curiosity and have somebody pay for it.”

item.title: Nazi Execution Photos Went Up For Sale. Greece Stopped It.
item.description: The images of political prisoners, taken just before they were killed by Nazis in 1944, were put up for auction on eBay. The sale was pulled shortly thereafter.
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: An image of Greek prisoners being led to their execution in 1944 was projected onto a wall at the site of the shootings, in Kaisariani, Greece, on Wednesday.

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.description: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Using different legal authorities, President Trump plans to impose a 10 percent global tariff and open investigations into certain, unspecified countries’ unfair trade practices.

item.title: Venezuela Releases Political Prisoners, With Conditions
item.description: Since Nicolás Maduro’s capture by the United States, Venezuela has released hundreds of political prisoners and approved a new amnesty law, although the restrictions on those freed have raised questions about whether this signals real change. Our international correspondent Simon Romero describes what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Leila Medina, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Patricia Sulbarán, Marian Carrasquero and Isayen Herrera

item.title: Johannes Dale-Skjevdal of Norway Wins Biathlon Mass Start
item.description: Johannes Dale-Skjevdal of Norway hit all 20 of his shots to win the gold medal in the mass start event.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine, Senators See War’s Impact and Press for Stronger U.S. Support
item.description: Senate Democrats traveled to Kyiv and Odessa to show solidarity with the war-torn nation and make the case that the United States should do more, including imposing harsh sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, on a tour of the Darnytsia power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, which was damaged in a Russian attack this month.

item.title: As Trump Considers Second Iran Attack, It Could Be Deadlier Than the First
item.description: Within days of the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities last year, all sides agreed to a cease-fire. This time could be different.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A missile display at a celebration in Tehran this month.

item.title: A Cancer Detection Test Fails in Major Study
item.description: A closely watched clinical trial in Britain that screened blood for early detection of cancer did not show a reduction in diagnoses at later stages of the disease.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Gina Kolata
item.media:description: The Galleri test looks for tiny shards of cancer DNA in the blood.

item.title: Head of Russia’s Antidoping Agency Was Involved in 2014 Doping Scheme, Whistle-Blower Claims
item.description: The accusation surfaced as Russia tries to re-establish its Olympics eligibility.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Veronika Loginova, director general of the Russian antidoping agency.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Iran Strikes, He Declines to Make Clear Case for Why
item.description: Rarely in modern times has the United States prepared to conduct a major act of war with so little explanation or public debate.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the inaugural Board of Peace meeting in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: How Did Draco Malfoy Get Mixed Up With Lunar New Year?
item.description: It all comes down to a love of wordplay.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca L. Davis
item.media:description: A Lunar New Year display showing a young Tom Felton as Draco Malfoy in Shangqiu, China, this month.

item.title: British Police Arrest Former Prince Andrew Amid Scrutiny Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, a longtime associate of Jeffrey Epstein, is being investigated on suspicion of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the brother of Britain’s King Charles III, leaving a police station on Thursday after his arrest on suspicion of misconduct in public office.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Casts Shadow Over UK Monarchy
item.description: The arrest of the former prince could shake public confidence in the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on King Charles III’s coronation day in 2023.

item.title: Alysa Liu Wins Figure Skating Gold in Stunning Comeback
item.description: Liu became the first American to win a medal in women’s figure skating since 2006.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Vincent Alban

item.title: Former Prince Andrew is the most senior British royal to have been arrested in modern times.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Police officers standing by an entrance to Wood Farm on the royal family’s Sandringham Estate, in Norfolk, England, where Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor was arrested on Thursday.

item.title: Austrian Man Found Guilty in Girlfriend’s Death on Mountain Hike
item.description: Thomas Plamberger was given a suspended prison sentence and fined in a case that tested the limits of personal responsibility in mountaineering.
item.dc:creator: Helena Smolak and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Complaint About Andrew’s Conduct Came From an Anti-Monarchy Group
item.description: Republic is the most prominent anti-monarchist movement in Britain and has about 140,000 registered supporters.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Activists from the anti-monarchy group Republic protesting at the entrance to Windsor Great Park and Royal Lodge, the previous residence of former Prince Andrew, in Windsor, England, last year.

item.title: How Has Sarah Ferguson, the Former Prince’s Ex-Wife, Responded to His Arrest?
item.description: There have been no public statements by his former wife or their two daughters.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Sarah Ferguson, the former Duchess of York, leaving St. George’s Chapel, in Windsor Castle, following an Easter Mattins Service, in 2024.

item.title: An Antarctic Voyage
item.description: My colleague just spent two months on a research icebreaker. It changed his perspective on the world in ways he didn’t expect.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: King Charles Attends a Fashion Event
item.description: His appearance comes after a statement of support for the investigation into his brother Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on suspicion of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III attends a Tolu Coker fashion show during London Fashion Week 2026 on Thursday.

item.title: A Lonely Baby Monkey Wins Hearts, and Even a Few Friends
item.description: Legions of fans from around the world have been cheering on Punch, a 7-month-old macaque who had been struggling to socialize at a zoo outside Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Punch with his plush companion at Ichikawa City Zoo.

item.title: The investigation continues though former Prince Andrew is released from police custody.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Members of the media at an entrance to Wood Farm on the British royal family’s Sandringham Estate in Norfolk, eastern England, on Thursday.

item.title: What to Know About Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest and His Ties to Epstein
item.description: King Charles III’s brother, who had already been stripped of his royal titles over ties to Jeffrey Epstein, was detained for several hours on Thursday on suspicions of misconduct in public office.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Prince Andrew, last year.

item.title: Here are the other British police departments looking into Epstein allegations.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling on Thursday near the gates of Royal Lodge, the former home of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor in Windsor Great Park, England.

item.title: House Democrats view Mountbatten-Windsor’s arrest as a step toward justice for the Epstein victims.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Representative Robert Garcia of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, at the microphones, after a deposition in the Jeffery Epstein case in New Albany, Ohio, on Wednesday. The fellow Democrats behind him, from left, are Representatives David Min of California, Yassamin Ansari of Arizona, Stephen F. Lynch of Massachusetts, and Jasmine Crockett of Texas.

item.title: In U.K. Police Detention Facilities, One-Person Cells and Simple Beds
item.description: The police have not said where they were holding Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, but the facilities are intended to hold people for short periods while they are questioned.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: The Thames Valley Police Headquarters in Kidlington, England. The force is the one that arrested Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on Thursday.

item.title: A British police force that serves as royal protectors arrested a former prince.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Windsor Castle on Thursday. Day to day, officers from the Thames Valley Police provide armed teams and mounted officers to guard the castle.

item.title: No Playbook for the Arrest of the UK King’s Brother
item.description: There is simply no blueprint for how to react to the arrest of a close relative of the king who until recently had played a senior role, and who could may be charged and put on trial, experts on the royals said.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and Duke of Edinburgh with their three sons, Edward, left, Charles and Andrew at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, in 1979.

item.title: A Rare Glimpse of a Sleeper Shark in Antarctic Waters
item.description: Researchers filmed a 10-to-13-foot sleeper shark off the South Shetland Islands, in what may be the first recording of the species that far south.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: The former prince gave a disastrous BBC interview in 2019.
item.description: T
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Who Is Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the Former Prince Arrested in the Epstein Inquiry?
item.description: The brother of King Charles III was a popular member of the royal family and adored by his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. He fell from grace because of his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Prince Andrew at Windsor Castle in 2024.

item.title: British Couple Held in Iran Is Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison, Family Says
item.description: Craig and Lindsay Foreman were arrested last year during a motorcycle tour around the world. Their relatives and the British government have rejected Iranian charges of “security crimes.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Craig and Lindsay Foreman, who have been sentenced to 10 years in prison in Iran, in a photograph released by their family.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew Is Accused of Misconduct in Public Office: What to Know
item.description: In Britain, the offense carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. No case has ever tested whether a member of Britain’s royal family could be considered a public officer.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, shown in 2022, was arrested on Thursday.

item.title: The police are investigating former Prince Andrew amid reports that he may have shared confidential information with Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor in 2009. He served as a trade envoy for the British government from 2001 to 2011.

item.title: The response from the authorities to the Epstein files has been far more aggressive in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The entrance on Thursday to Wood Farm at the Sandringham Estate in Norfolk, where Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor has been living.

item.title: Assault on Sudanese City Bore ‘Hallmarks of Genocide,’ U.N. Finds
item.description: A paramilitary group in Sudan’s civil war “acted with genocidal intent” in a monthslong siege of El Fasher, according to human rights experts.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sudanese refugees from different parts of north Darfur, including El Fasher, crossing into Chad in November.

item.title: The former Prince Andrew was stripped of his royal titles late last year.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The former Prince Andrew attends the funeral of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, in 2022.

item.title: The former prince has been living on King Charles III’s private Sandringham Estate.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Marsh Farm, on the Sandringham Estate in Sandringham, Norfolk, this month. Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor moved to the estate after leaving the Royal Lodge in Windsor.

item.title: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s Links to Jeffrey Epstein: A Timeline
item.description: The association, which began in 1999, cost the former Prince Andrew his royal titles and status, and his reputation before his arrest.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A photograph of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor with Virginia Giuffre in 2001, in Ms. Giuffre’s book. She said in a civil case that she was forced to have sex with him when he was a prince.

item.title: Where Things Stand on Witkoff and Kushner’s Negotiations Over Iran, Ukraine and Gaza
item.description: Iran, Ukraine and Gaza are in play as the Trump envoys conduct talks on all of them. But progress in each conflict is scant.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Jared Kushner, right, President Trump’s son-in-law; and Steve Witkoff, the U.S. special envoy, during the World Economic Forum last month.
